Dear Dr. Harrison,

IMF's argument hinges on a corruption of the word "subsidy". Reject that corruption, and the argument collapses.

I have always found that careful use of language is a great aid to clear thinking.

According to my Universal English Dictionary (H.C.Wyld, ed., Waverly Books, London, UK) a subsidy is "A direct grant of public money to support or assist private industry or enterprise."

Therefore a political decision not to tax something is not a subsidy. It is a political decision to steal less profit from a healthy enterprise than demanded by competing special interests.

In Alice in Wonderland the Red Queen insisted "Words mean exactly what I want them to mean when I say them."

So it is only in the Red Queen's infinitely flexible lexicon, now adopted by the IMF, that "failure to tax a commodity vital to modern economic life at rates sufficient to assuage environmentalists' ever-shifting fears of possible climate catastrophe at some ever-retreating unknown future date" becomes
a "subsidy".

The Red Queen would understand, because to control the definition of the terms to be debated is to seize control of the debate.

I reject this attempt to redefine reduced government theft as "subsidy" and I urge you to reject the IMF's bizarre line of twisted logic.

I'm so sorry that the medical system has so many cracks in it, and that you and your husband have fallen through some of them.

Some cancer centers do provide other services to support their patients. Although my treatment was at a center in a smallish city, I met early on with a dietitian to help understand the challenges of keeping meat on my bones during treatment. And my radiation oncologist was willing to discuss literally anything that related to my condition. When I broke down and asked for a feeding tube I was referred to a home health company and another dietitian who managed that care along with a 24-hour help line, which I did need sometimes. My RO was in contact with the ENT who referred me to him, and together they answered every question I had--and there were many! I was very well informed about the many terrible side effects of my treatment. And the center had a nurse practitioner who could deal with any medical issues that came up, whether or not they were actually related to the cancer radiation. There were also help groups for those who wanted them.

In the 4+ years since, I have met man online who did not get anthing close to the support I did. I thank my doctors at every opportunity for helping me understand and cope with the effects of this terrible disease and its treatment.

My suggestion is to find help online if you can't get it in person.
No jail, no justice. People died from a lack of care. This is more than just fraud.

When it comes to donating to non-profits, like anything else, due diligence is very important.

We can address fraud and still honor good work that helps support a Democracy. These articles inevitably bring out the cranks who claim that the charitable sector is corrupt. Even if you don't believe in charity, that is simply false.

Never a day goes by when there are stories across the country about small town nonprofits and causes misusing donations. The 1787 Constitution was a good "first draft" for a new secular republic amidst a then sea of theistic monarchies, and enacted at the price of slavery, and disenfranchisement of the Native American, even those who had supported the white rebel Americans during the Revolution.
Jefferson in his lifetime called for a Constitutional Convention every 50 years, because "no future American deserves to live under the dead hand of the past."
We got rid of slavery by preventing 11 states from voting on the issue.
When a civil war occurs, it is proof that your governing document is a failure; it's job is to resolve political disputes, peacefully.
When the North won the war, we failed to call a Constitutional Convention to modernize the governing document.
Today, all the structure of the 1787 document that was built into defending slavery, still remains: 50% of the US Senate represents 17% of the population; filibuster or threat of same; partisan gerrymandering; restricted ballot access for candidates of minority parties; lack of Federal control and administration of the franchise process for the 5 Federal elective offices; and many more failings.
The 1787 version was a square wheel. What we have today is a 6 sided wheel. We also have 36% voter turn-out, i.e. 64% voter stiff rate, for Congressional elections, and a 46% voter stiff rate for Prez elections, and we wonder why we have a non-functional Congress...

I frequently visited the New York World Fair in both 1964 and 1965. For that adolescent, the celebration of imagination, optimism and joy of the World's Fair was crushed by a growing awareness of racism and the poverty and oppression of the African-American community and then the tragic blunder of this nation into a long and futile war in Southeast Asia.

The tragedy is that 50 years later racism and the poverty and oppression of the African-American community and another long and futile war in Southwest Asia have probably crushed the imagination, optimism and joy of another generation of America's youth.
